nodes.text: Maximizing social welfare by choosing taxes and public production leads to aggregate production efficiency being desirable in a wide variety of circumstances when taxes are set optimally, and yields an optimal commodity tax structure

Aggregate production efficiency (equal marginal rates of transformation across public and private production) is desirable at the social optimum provided the social cost of additional resources is positive and appropriate tax instruments exist

Optimal tax structure equates marginal social benefit of an infinitesimal price change to the social cost of supplying the induced change in demand, producing first-order conditions that relate consumer prices, producer prices, and taxes (Ramsey-type conditions)

Approach: analyze a special one-consumer two-commodity case geometrically, then use calculus for an algebraic one-consumer model with public and private production, and extend to many consumers with rigorous theorems

Algebraic derivation (one-consumer, constant returns private sector, consumer prices q and producer prices p related by taxes t) yields Lagrangian first-order conditions implying fk = gk and thus equal public and private marginal rates of transformation when Lagrange multiplier X is nonzero
If X equals zero (no social cost of marginal resources) the efficiency conclusion may fail; sections III and IV provide conditions guaranteeing X nonzero and justify efficiency
When several public production sectors exist, each sector's marginal rate of transformation equals the private sector's, implying equality across all public sectors as well

First-order conditions can be written as proportionality between marginal utility of a price change and the change in tax revenue from a tax rate change at constant producer prices; in the individualistic welfare case this implies a constant ratio of marginal tax revenue to quantity across commodities
Interpretation: optimal taxes can be characterized without analyzing price responses to government actions at the margin because first-order conditions are expressed at constant prices

Geometric one-consumer analysis: the planner choosing consumer prices faces production feasibility and consumer offer-curve constraints; the optimal decentralized outcome lies on the production frontier when lump-sum transfers are unavailable

Extension to many consumers: indirect welfare V(q)=U(x1(q),...,xH(q)); under mild continuity and preference assumptions and availability of commodity taxes (or a poll subsidy) the efficiency conclusion for aggregate production carries over

Rigorous results: Theorems establishing existence of an optimum (under continuity, boundedness, convexity assumptions) and Lemma giving conditions under which optimal production lies on the production frontier; these guarantee X nonzero and justify efficiency

Counterexamples and limitations: examples where optimal production is interior (not weakly efficient) occur when welfare or endowments create discontinuities or symmetries; constraints on tax instruments or presence of pure profits can invalidate efficiency

Extensions and implications: (a) intermediate good taxes are undesirable because efficiency across integrated production implies no tax on intermediate transactions; (b) untaxable sectors, international trade, migration, consumption externalities, and consumer capital market imperfections change the optimal tax formulas but generally do not overturn aggregate production efficiency if continuity holds

Specific limitation: constant returns and no profits in private sector are crucial for the no-intermediate-tax and efficiency results; when these fail or when taxes cannot be levied on relevant transactions, optimal efficiency conclusions may not hold
